facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 74 of 1971 is before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 74 of 197 1.

facts.text: Appeal is from judgment and order dated June 17, 1970 of Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 35 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 17, 1970 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeal No. 35 of 1967.

facts.text: Madras High Court judgment delivered by Veeraswami, C.J. and Gokulakrishnan, J. dismissed the appeal filed by plaintiffs-appellants.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is directed against the judgment of the Madras High Court  Veeraswami, C.J., and Gokula- krishnan, J.  dismissing the appeal filed by the plaintiffs- appellants

facts.text: Trial judgment and decree by Kunhamed Kutti, J. dated February 20, 1967 in ordinary original civil jurisdiction of Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment and decree of Kunhamed Kutti, J., dated February 20, 1967, made in the exercise of the ordinary original civil jurisdiction of the Madras High Court.

facts.text: Plaintiffs leased plot of land on Mount Road, Madras to defendant No. 1 under duly registered lease deed dated November 17, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs had filed a suit on the following allegations. The plaintiffs who were landlords leased to defendant No. the plot of land on Mount Road, Madras, under a duty registered lease deed dated November 17, 1938,

facts.text: Lease period was 15 years 3 months from March 1, 1939 at rent of Rs. 560 per month.

anchor.surface_text: for a period of 15 years 3 months from March 1, 1939 at a rent of Rs. 560/- per month on the terms and companyditions set out therein

facts.text: Lease included option for renewal in favour of defendant No. 1 for further 10 years from March 1, 1954 at enhanced rent of Rs. 630 per month.

anchor.surface_text: with an option for renewal in favour of defendant No. 1 for a further period of 10 years from March 1, 1954 but at an enhanced rent of Rs. 630/- per month, and subject to the other stipulations

facts.text: Lease required lessee to erect theatre on demised plot costing not less than Rs. 50,000 within reasonable period.

anchor.surface_text: The Leasee companyenants with the Lessors as follows Within a reasonable period from the date hereof, at his own companyt and charges, under the supervision of the Lessors and in accordance with plans, elevations, sections and specifications to be first approved by the Lessors erect, companyer in and companyplete in a substantial and workmen like manner on the demised plot of land, a theatre with all proper 2 9 3 officers and out buildings such as bazars, restaurants,, motor and dunamo sheds etc., and fences, drains, sewers to be used for production and exhibition of films and for staging Drama therein and to, expend in building such theatre a sum of number less than Rs. 50,0001-.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 constructed a theatre on the plot in accordance with lease stipulations.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. 1 in accordance with the stipulations -in the lease deed, companystructed a theatre on the said plot and the same has been used for exhibition of cinema films by him.

facts.text: Theatre used for exhibition of cinema films by defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: and the same has been used for exhibition of cinema films by him.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 exercised option of renewal of lease for 10 years from March 1, 1954 and continued in possession till expiry with February 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. I exercised the option of renewal ,,of lease for the further period of 10 years from March 1, 1954 and has been companytinuing in possession for- a full further term of 10 years from March 1, 1954 expiring with ,the month of February, 1.964.

facts.text: Plaintiffs exercised option to buy buildings by letter dated February 27, 1964 and sent Rs. 50,000 by cheque without deducting depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the terms of clause 4  d  of the lease deed, the plaintiffs exercised the option of buying the buildings erected on the demised land by letter dated Feb- ruary 27, 1964 and sent alongwith the full amount of Rs. 50,000/- by cheque in payment for all the superstructures without deducting any amount for depreciation,

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 refused Rs. 50,000 and contended plaintiffs not entitled to enforce clause 4(d) or offer Rs. 50,000 as price.

anchor.surface_text: Defendant No. I however, refused the sum of Rs. 50,0001- and companytended that the plaintiffs were number entitled to claim any rights on the footing of clause 4  d  of the lease deed or to offer the sum of Rs. 50,0001- as the price for purchasing the superstructure put up by him on the land leased to him.

facts.text: Plaintiffs filed suit on allegations regarding lease and option.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs had filed a suit on the following allegations.

facts.text: Supreme Court construed Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921 as amended by 1955 Act in prior cases.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises before us is whether the plaintiffs were entitled to enforce clause 4  d  of the lease deed in view of the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921, as amended by the Amending Act of 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court held case covered by Mylapore Hindu Permanent Fund Ltd. v. K. S. Subramania Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the case is companyered by the judgment in the Mylapore Hindu Permanent Fund case 2 .

facts.text: Lease clauses amount to stipulations as to erection of buildings, proviso to S.12 applies.

anchor.surface_text: We have set out the relevant clauses of the lease deed in this case and it seems to us that these clauses amount to a stipulation as to the erection of buildings and companysequently the proviso to S. 12 applies.

facts.text: Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921 passed in 1922 to protect tenants who constructed buildings on others' lands.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921, was passed in 1922 to give protection to certain classes of tenants who had companystructed buildings on others lands in the hope that they would number be evicted so long as they paid a fair rent for the land.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied for amendment of plaint dated April 15, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs-appellants applied for amendment of their plaint dated April 15, 1964, by adding the following words in the Prayer Clauses  a  after the words as from 1-3-1964

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed amendment to plaint.

anchor.surface_text: We allowed the amendment to be made.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside judgments of Single Judge and Division Bench, decreed suit in terms of amended prayers a and b.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, the judgments of the Single Judge and the Division Bench set aside and the suit decreed in terms of prayers  a  and  b  as amended.

facts.text: Mesne profits for use and occupation from August 4, 1968 till possession handed over.

anchor.surface_text: That the defendants do pay the plaintiffs the sum of Rs. 12,000  twelve thousand  per month as mesne profits for use and occupation of the buildings and superstructures built upon the demised premises from 4-8-1968 till possession is handed over to the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Case remitted to Trial Judge to determine mesne profits from August 4, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The case will number go back to the Trial Judge to determine the mesne profits for use and occupation from August 4, 1968 till the possession is handed over to the plaintiffs in accordance with law.

facts.text: Possession to be handed over within six months from judgment date.

anchor.surface_text: Possession will be handed over within six months from today.

facts.text: Parties to bear own costs throughout.

anchor.surface_text: The parties will bear their own companyts throughout.
Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921, as amended by the Amending Act of 1955.

concepts.unlisted_description: Act passed in 1922 to protect tenants who constructed buildings on leased lands from eviction provided they pay fair rent.

anchor.surface_text: the first part of Section 12 protects a tenant against the deprivation or limitation of his rights under the Act and the rights conferred by the Act do not directly relate to covenants relating to erection of buildings.

concepts.interpretation: Section 12 protects tenant rights under the Act but does not directly relate to covenants on erection of buildings.

anchor.surface_text: It must be remembered that the Madras City Tenants Protection Act, 1921, was passed in 1922 to give protection to certain classes of tenants who had constructed buildings on others lands in the hope that they would not be evicted so long as they paid a fair rent for the land. holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation: Act protects tenants paying rent but respects registered pre-existing stipulations on buildings

The case will number go back to the Trial Judge to determine the mesne profits for use and occupation from August 4, 1968 till the possession is handed over to the plaintiffs in accordance with law. The parties will bear their own costs throughout. Possession will be handed over within six months from today. In the meantime respondent No.
